title: Could the EU referendum results be overturned?
text:
Could the EU referendum results be overturned? 17:30, 24 Jun 2016 There's a glimmer of hope for those wanting the UK to remain in the European Union Shares The video will start in 8 s Cancel Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
Is all lost for those who cling to the dream that the UK remain part of the European Union ? 
For those looking for straws to clutch at, how about the following. 
The vote to Leave is not actually legally binding as it is parliament and not the voters who make that decision. 
Legal experts have pointed out the Brexit vote is “advisory,” not “mandatory”. 
As such MPs can legally disregard the public’s will and decide the path Britain chooses. So what could happen next? 
The options of course include supporting the result but on the flipside MPs can choose to ignore it. Pro-EU ministers have an overwhelming cross-party support in parliament, with less than 200 of the 650 MPs supporting the Leave campaign. 
A Commons vote could put pressure on the government to keep the UK inside the single market. 
Another option is to renegotiate a deal with the EU making it more palatable to the British public and then holding another referendum. 
Fanciful, you might think. But here’s the thing. In February Boris Johnson, the early favourite to replace David Cameron as Prime Minister, intimated just that. 
In his Daily Telegraph column he wrote: “EU history shows that they only really listen to a population when it says ‘no’”. He has previously suggested that only by voting to Leave would the country “get the change we need”. This was widely interpreted as advocating a second referendum. 
However he later back tracked, saying “out was out”. 
There is another scenario which could, theoretically, see the result overturned. 
This is if MPs forced a general election and a party campaigned on a promise to keep Britain in the EU, got elected and then claimed that the election mandate topped the referendum one. How likely would that be? 
Very unlikely, say experts. 
Many commentators, argue it would be “political suicide” if the government were to dismiss the result of a democratic vote. 
It is only when Article 50 is invoked that it all become legally binding, the timing of which is something Mr Cameron has left to his successor. 
So there’s still some time left. More on the EU Referendum
